title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.16.20 Part 1 | 22-01-2023
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyana Timiraandhasya Gyananjanishalakaya Chaksharunmilitam Yena Dasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras, invoking blessings and paying respects to the spiritual master.

segments.key_quote: So different questions raised by Dharma are indicative of the different ways people suffer in Kali Yuga due to this age.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the 20th verse of the 16th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, explaining that it describes Dharma's lamentations to Mother Earth about the suffering in Kali Yuga.

segments.key_quote: With the progress of the age of Kali, four things particularly namely the duration of life, mercy, the power of recollection and moral or religious principles will gradually diminish.
segments.summary: Srila Prabhupada's purport is introduced, focusing on the diminishing qualities of life, mercy, memory, and morality in Kali Yuga, referencing the 12th canto of Srimad Bhagavatam.

segments.key_quote: People are losing that sense of compassion for the fellow human being
segments.summary: The speaker illustrates the decline of compassion in Kali Yuga with the example of people's indifference to those in need, contrasting it with past behavior and highlighting increasing selfishness.

segments.key_quote: People are becoming more and more irreligious, immoral, immoral, irreligious.
segments.summary: The lecture continues discussing the diminishing power of recollection and moral/religious principles in Kali Yuga, emphasizing the rise of irreligion, immorality, and cruelty, especially towards cows and bulls.

segments.key_quote: Since dharma or the principles of religion would be lost in the proportion of three out of four, the symbolic bull was standing on one leg only.
segments.summary: The speaker explains the symbolism of Dharma standing on one leg, representing the loss of religious principles, and notes that three-fourths of the world's population is becoming irreligious at the beginning of Kali Yuga.

segments.key_quote: Chanting Hare Krishna is the best way of atoning for all sinful activities
segments.summary: The speaker describes the extreme degradation expected towards the end of Kali Yuga, focusing on the widespread killing of cows and the severe karmic consequences, and emphasizes chanting Hare Krishna and avoiding sinful activities as a means of atonement and salvation.
